results.title: The Living mammal
results.brief_description: Common characteristics held by all mammals. Various ways in which mammals have adapted themselves to life in the water, air, treetops and on the ground. The highly developed senses of sight, smell, touch and hearing combined in the hunt for food. The adaptations of teeth for herbivorous, carnivorous and ominivorous modes of life. Methods of self-protection and ways in which different mammals care for and rear their young.

results.title: The Living laboratory
results.creator_credit: Raymond Hancock and Department of Information, Government of South Africa
results.brief_description: A survey of South Africa’s varied scientific progress. It is an area which has stimulated pioneering scientists in the widening fields of archaeology and anthropology. A vast spectrum of ancient and modern life and living patterns provides sociologists, ecologists, veterinary and medical scientists with research material.

results.title: The Living goddess
results.creator_credit: Josette Heimans, Frank Heimans, Cinetel Productions and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Kumari, a virgin girl-child is installed as a deity in Nepal, and wields more power among her people than almost any other living person. Shows ceremonial and religious pageant of her accession in Nepal. Written and narrated by Paul Ricketts.

results.title: The Living gallery
results.creator_credit: Laurence Hyde and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Recreation for children and adults is a problem for every community. The Art Gallery of Toronto provides many activities in addition to the usual tours and conducted parties. For children there are classes in art, hobby work, story-telling and other creative projects. Art becomes more than gazing at pictures.

results.title: The Living Forest (Captioned)
results.brief_description: As populations expand so do the demands being made on forests to provide living space and forest products. If the forest is to continue to supply our needs, what are the appropriate measures required to conserve it? This program is a detailed study of the ecology of a eucalypt forest and the many plants and animals which make up the forest community.

results.title: The Living forest
results.creator_credit: Tom Morrison, Ken J. Widdowson and Victorian Forests Commission
results.brief_description: A film which shows how man is making heavy demands on the earth’s remaining forests. A detailed study is made of the ecology of a eucalypt forest and the many plants and animals which make up the forest environment.

results.title: The Living filter
results.creator_credit: Pennsylvania State University and Hornbein-Wood Films
results.brief_description: Describes an experiment in which municipal waste water was used to irrigate forest and farmland, thereby increasing plant growth and purifying the water to drinking quality. The experiment also suggests the potential use of the technique in reclaiming strip-mined land.
results.description: Describes an experiment in which municipal waste water was used to irrigate forest and farmland, thereby increasing plant growth and purifying the water to drinking quality. The experiment also suggests the potential use of the technique in reclaiming strip-mined land.

results.title: The Living end
results.creator_credit: Gregg Araki, Jim Stark, Marcus Hu, Jon Gerrans and Desperate Pictures
results.brief_description: On its release in the early 1990s, “The Living end” became one of the key films of the New Queer Cinema movement. Refuting both the conservatism of contemporary Hollywood and the increasingly bourgeois codes of “positive stereotyping” found in much of gay and lesbian cinema, Gregg Araki’s film celebrates and explores the sexual outlaws at the margins of Western gay life. Luke is a gay prostitute who lives on the streets. Jon is a sensitive movie critic who lives a comfortable, sterile life. The one thing they share in common is that they are both HIV+ and when they fall for each other they set about on a murderous road trip, killing anyone who gets in their way: macho homophobes, up-tight dykes, bitchy queens. Unlike films such as “Longtime companion” which attempted to homogenise and de-radicalise the experience of living with AIDS, “The Living end” shocked many viewers by placing two unapologetic survivors, whose anger and hatred is not muted, at the centre of its narrative. Araki’s low-budget aesthetic, influenced by equal measures of love for both punk music and the cinema of the French Nouvelle Vague, allowed him to create a truly dynamic, rough but wickedly subversive comedy road movie. Its humour, and its emotional vitality, remain undiluted.

results.title: The Living desert
results.creator_credit: James Algar, Ben Sharpsteen and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: A photographic study of plant and animal life in the arid plain which stretches from Oregon to Mexico and from California to Texas. Includes scenes of a death struggle between a hawk and a rattlesnake, an encounter between a bobcat and wild pigs, the pursuit of a kangaroo rat and her babies by a Kingsnake, a contest between two male turtles for the favour of a female, the courtship dance of a pair of scorpions by moonlight, and a time-lapse sequence showing desert wild flowers coming into bloom. Narrated by Winston Hibler.
